content:
Diagnosis:	Stage IV rectal adenocarcinoma, initially diagnosed March 2015 with liver and lung metastases confirmed on CT. KRAS mutant.?

Treatment:		Total mesorectal excision April 2015 with partial hepatectomy for synchronous liver metastases.?
			Completed adjuvant CAPOX June 2015.?
			Progression noted in February 2018 with new pulmonary metastases; started on FOLFOX with bevacizumab.?
			Discontinued FOLFOX December 2019 due to neurotoxicity.?
			Initiated nivolumab as part of clinical trial March 2020; ceased June 2022 following progression.?
			Recent imaging August 2024 showed progression in hepatic lesions and new peritoneal implants.?

[redacted name] attended today's clinic reporting significant fatigue and difficulty managing daily tasks, requiring increased use of home aids. He describes ongoing right-sided abdominal pain, rated 6/10, managed with regular paracetamol and occasional tramadol. His appetite is reduced with a 4kg weight loss over 3 months.?

Examination revealed mild pallor, no jaundice, and moderate ascites with tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Performance status has declined to ECOG 2.?

Recent Investigations:
? CT August 2024: Progression in liver metastases (largest lesion 3.5cm â†’ 5.2cm) and new peritoneal disease.?
? CEA risen from 23 to 78 over 4 months.?
? Bloods show mild hypoalbuminemia (32g/L) and elevated alkaline phosphatase (185U/L).?

Plan:
? Discontinue current therapy (irinotecan-based) due to progression.?
? Initiate regorafenib with dose escalation protocol.?
? Prescribe spironolactone 50mg daily for ascites management.?
? Refer to palliative care for quality-of-life support and symptom management.?
? Schedule repeat CT abdomen/pelvis in 8 weeks to assess response.?
? Follow-up clinic visit in 3 weeks for regorafenib tolerance assessment.
